G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, because this Court entered the existing custody and parenting time order, and the parties and the Children reside within the jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, because this Court entered the existing custody and parenting time order, and the parties and the Children reside within the jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the Court’s general equity powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6, seeking modification of custody and parenting time provisions based on a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the Children.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the Court’s general equity powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6, seeking modification of custody and parenting time provisions based on a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the Children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The paramount consideration in all custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount consideration in all custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the governing standard in custody cases and traces the history of the ‘best interests of the child’ test, explicitly characterizing it as the controlling, paramount consideration in custody and visitation determinations. The court reaffirms that this standard is the touchstone for deciding custody and parenting-time arrangements and applies it to resolve the dispute, so the case directly supports the proposition stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The paramount consideration in all custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the custody analysis in terms of the effects on the child, including requiring explicit findings about domestic violence and its impact on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect. While the case focuses on domestic violence, its reasoning treats the "best interests of the child"—particularly the child’s safety and well-being—as the controlling standard in custody and parenting time, consistent with the proposition. The opinion does not use the exact quoted phrase, but its analysis is clearly structured around that principle.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. ... We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below "fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability." ... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Modification requires a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the prior judgment, and that modification be in the best interests of the child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the proper criteria for an initial custody award in a divorce judgment, focusing on the child’s welfare and best interests. It does not discuss standards for *modification* of an existing custody or support order, nor does it mention any requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific modification standard described in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Modification requires a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the prior judgment, and that modification be in the best interests of the child.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is an appeal from an original divorce and custody judgment, not a proceeding to modify an existing custody or support order. The court discusses the ‘best interests of the children’ standard for custody and visitation, but it does not address what is required to obtain a modification of a prior judgment, nor does it mention any need to show a material and substantial change in circumstances. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for the modification standard stated in the proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Modification requires a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the prior judgment, and that modification be in the best interests of the child.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the governing standard for modifying a custody provision in a divorce judgment: there must be a material and substantial change in circumstances and the modification must be necessary in the best interests of the child. This language directly tracks the proposition claimed, and the court applies that standard in reviewing the change from shared to sole legal custody.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’”

Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013).proposition: Courts recognize that significant changes in a parent’s employment, work schedule, or ability to personally provide care can constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances warranting review of an existing parenting plan.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of a child support order, not modification of a parenting plan or custody/parenting schedule. Its discussion of ‘material and substantial change’ is only in the context of child support, and the holding replaces that standard with the statutory ‘inconsistency’ standard for support modifications. The case does not address changes in a parent’s employment, work schedule, or caregiving ability as grounds for modifying a parenting plan, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013).relevant_excerpt: “Prior to its amendment in 1993 … § 28 provided that the material and substantial change standard was the correct standard for determining whether to modify a custody judgment or a child support order. … The 1993 amendment to § 28 clearly separated custody determinations from child support orders, applying the material and substantial change standard to modifications of custody orders and the inconsistency standard to modifications of child support orders.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Courts recognize that significant changes in a parent’s employment, work schedule, or ability to personally provide care can constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances warranting review of an existing parenting plan.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss what qualifies as a “material and substantial change in circumstances,” but the only change it identifies is the mother’s successful rehabilitation from alcohol and drug dependence. It does not mention changes in employment, work schedule, or the parent’s ability to personally provide care as the basis for modification. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition that employment-related or caregiving-availability changes constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28… enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children… In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’ … Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Courts recognize that significant changes in a parent’s employment, work schedule, or ability to personally provide care can constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances warranting review of an existing parenting plan.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely rejects the idea that the mother’s hectic work schedule and need for childcare constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances. The court explicitly states that a working parent with a hectic schedule can still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that the changes in the mother’s work schedule were positive and not grounds for custody modification. Thus, the case stands for the opposite of the claimed proposition and does not recognize employment or schedule changes here as material changes warranting review of the parenting plan.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: "The probate judge found that, following the divorce, '[b]ecause both parties were working full-time ... the minor child was in need of and received daycare.' She also found that '[t]he Mother’s work schedule was quite hectic. ...' We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a 'hectic' schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification. Second, by the time of trial, the probate judge found that positive changes in the mother’s work schedule ... were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement."

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: The Father’s new overnight work schedule and the resulting instability and unpredictability in overnight care constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the Children’s welfare within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable case law, including Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981); Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); and Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013).
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: Schuler concerns modification of alimony and child support based on the payor’s financial changes, not custody or parenting-time changes. The opinion interprets G.L. c. 208, § 28 in terms of financial ability to pay and needs of the children, but does not address work schedules, overnight care, or instability in custodial arrangements as a material change in circumstances. Citing Schuler for the proposition that a father’s new overnight work schedule and resulting instability in overnight care constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances misstates what the case holds.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28… A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support award.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts have emphasized that a stable, predictable schedule and safe, continuous care are central to the “best interests of the child” analysis.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties the statutory ‘best interests of the child’ standard to preserving existing caregiving arrangements and minimizing disruption, stressing that stability, continuity, and maintaining the status quo are ordinarily in the child’s best interests. The court criticizes temporary orders that undermine a child’s stable living arrangement and emphasizes that unnecessary changes to an existing, satisfactory custodial schedule increase the risk of harm, which aligns with the proposition about the centrality of a stable, predictable schedule and continuous care to the best-interests analysis.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “These efforts also reflect the view that it is in the ‘best interests of the child’ to preserve the current placement with a parent, if it is a satisfactory one, and that stability and continuity with the child’s primary caregiver is itself an important factor in a child’s successful upbringing…. If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: Massachusetts courts have emphasized that a stable, predictable schedule and safe, continuous care are central to the “best interests of the child” analysis.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the necessity of explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child when making custody determinations. While it discusses the child’s bond with the father and his school performance, it does not articulate a general principle that a stable, predictable schedule and safe, continuous care are central to the best‑interests analysis. The central doctrinal emphasis is on accounting for domestic violence, not on schedules or continuity of care as such.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below 'fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.' ... The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. ... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking."

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).proposition: Massachusetts courts have emphasized that a stable, predictable schedule and safe, continuous care are central to the “best interests of the child” analysis.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses best interests and parental fitness in broad terms, focusing on parental rights, unfitness, and improper reliance on lifestyle differences, but it does not specifically emphasize a “stable, predictable schedule” or “safe, continuous care” as central articulated factors in the best-interests analysis. Stability and continuity appear only indirectly, in references to the child’s bonded relationship with the caretaker and the need for expedited custody decisions, and the court ultimately reverses without adopting the trial judge’s stability-based reasoning. Thus, the case is not strong authority for the specific proposition stated.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).relevant_excerpt: “We recognize that the lengthy separation of a mother and child and a corresponding growth in the ties between the child and a different custodian may in some circumstances indicate that the forced return of the child to the mother would be seriously detrimental to the child, with the result that the mother should be deemed not fit to care for the child. … The judge’s conclusions from his subsidiary findings state that ‘[t]he sudden cleavage of a bonded relationship lasting over three years between a surrogate mother and the minor child of tender years, where the child has achieved for the first time, a stable, loving and devoted relationship could and would cause irreparable harm….’”}

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 265–266 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Court may, and should, consider each parent’s ability to personally care for the Children during his or her scheduled parenting time, including the extent to which the parent must rely on third parties.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss each parent’s work schedule and use of childcare, and it notes that working outside the home and having a ‘hectic’ schedule alone does not justify a custody change. But the case is primarily about (1) the need for a material and substantial change in circumstances to modify custody and (2) the proper application of removal standards. It does not articulate or endorse a distinct principle that the court ‘may, and should’ weigh each parent’s ability to personally care for the child during parenting time versus reliance on third parties; rather, it treats the mother’s work and childcare arrangements as non-dispositive and not a valid basis for modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “The probate judge found that, following the divorce, ‘[b]ecause both parties were working full-time ... the minor child was in need of and received daycare.’ She also found that ‘[t]he Mother’s work schedule was quite hectic. . . . [Her] schedule is a combination of odd hours and concert schedules.’ … We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–739 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The Court may, and should, consider each parent’s ability to personally care for the Children during his or her scheduled parenting time, including the extent to which the parent must rely on third parties.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on best‑interests analysis in a custody‑modification context, emphasizing factors such as sibling unity, children’s preferences, parental fitness, and the weight of GAL and other testimony. It does not discuss, even implicitly, a comparative assessment of each parent’s ability to personally care for the children during parenting time or the extent of reliance on third parties. Because the court neither articulates nor applies that specific factor, this case does not support the claimed proposition.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Discretion allows the judge, when determining the best interests of children, to consider the widest range of permissible evidence, including the reports and testimony of a court appointed investigator or G.A.L., evidence of the history of the relationship between the child and each parent, evidence of each parent’s present home environment and overall fitness to further the child’s best interests, and the judge’s own impressions upon interviewing the child privately in chambers.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Courts have recognized that when changed circumstances impact a child’s schedule, safety, or consistent care, modification of custody or parenting time is appropriate to realign the order with the child’s best interests.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842\u20138.proposition: A modified schedule that limits overnights to times when the Father is off work and available, while preserving his meaningful relationship with the Children, advances the Children’s best interests and is consistent with Massachusetts law favoring frequent and continuing contact with both parents when such contact is in the child’s best interests.
